{{champion:44}} {{item:3151}} {{item:3135}} {{item:3020}} {{item:3033}} {{item:3142}} {{item:3147}}

Gotta penetrate deeper.

When it belongs in the M&G section...

But in all seriousness, if this were a legit Gameplay post I'd have to say {{champion:56}}

people think that guy needs to be reworked, but all i have to say to it is:

did you see what riot did to rengar?

Tbh, I think Rengar's Q would be interesting on nocturne, but i also love nocturne's current kit. He fights best in his own realm (Q domain). As it is, I love playing noc, but sometimes he feels like a very... Stat-check champ.
Q'd enemy? Check
E up? Check
R? Check
Few items? Check

I still cant find an issue with statchecking as a whole, but kinda want more of an explanation on why people have so much against it.  from my point of view, i would be pretty upset if i got all these stats and it felt like i got "cheesed" because of how much the opponent could avoid.

I still almost never get a negative kda on nocturne when i play him, though.

I have a pretty good track record on nocturne as well, for the most part.

It's mainly because it doesn't feel intuitive. People like to play champs that feel good to play.  Stat checking doesn't exactly feel "good" to play as, or against.  I can't say much about others, but personally I like to feel as if I won due to my own skill, with my own abilities as a person, while the champion I'm playing is a tool in which for me to do so. I have my favorite champions/tools in which I do better with.  I don't like winning, and then thinking to myself, "Oh thank GOD my champion is stronger than theirs is."  Like watching {{champion:266}} fight {{champion:12}} with nothing but auto attacks.
Or {{champion:24}} vs {{champion:11}} when jax has his dodge up every 5 seconds.

but wouldn't this mean you aren't playing to win? and how would it not feel "intuitive"? whats not intuitive is to have a champ that worked hard at getting all its stats lose a duel because someone could utuilize mechanics better who barely had any stats.

Nope, I play primarily to have fun.  My goal is to win, yes but It's second to enjoying the game.  And we call that an "outplay" Like a Vayne utilizing her ult's invisibility and a nearby brush to pop in and out of sight, kite,  and whittle down the {{champion:6}} fighting her. The urgot could have also just warded the bush she's using and then disrupt vayne's damage until her ult ends, and go in for the kill.

Oh. You know. I thought you were actually being serious. 

To which I still say though, {{champion:38}} {{champion:141}} {{champion:121}}

**Sigh**
That joke gets old, you know.
I will just pretent that was a genuine question:
